chh.util

Class Color

  • java.lang.Object
    • chh.util.Color

  • public class Color
extends java.lang.Object
    A Color object represents any 256-bit color that can be displayed in a pixel.
    Version:
    2013.07.17
    Author:
    Christopher H. Harvey

    • Constructor Summary

      Constructors 
      Constructor and Description
      Color()
      Constructs a new Color, default to black.
      Color(int red, int green, int blue)
      Constructs a new Color object, given three priamary color components.
      Color(java.lang.String hex)
      Creates a new color given a hexadecimal code in #RRGGBB format.

    • Constructor Detail

      • Color

        public Color(int red,
     int green,
     int blue)
        Constructs a new Color object, given three priamary color components.
        Parameters:
        red - the red component of this color. Must be between 0 and 255.
        green - the green component of this color. Must be between 0 and 255.
        blue - the blue component of this color. Must be between 0 and 255.

      • Color

        public Color()
        Constructs a new Color, default to black.

      • Color

        public Color(java.lang.String hex)
        Creates a new color given a hexadecimal code in #RRGGBB format.
        Parameters:
        hex - a six-digit hexadecimal number preceded by a hash symbol (#), as a String

    • Method Detail

      • getRed

        Returns the red component.
        Returns:
        the red component of this color

        public final int getGreen()
        Returns the green component.
        Returns:
        the green component of this color

      • getBlue

        public final int getBlue()
        Returns the blue component.
        Returns:

      • getHSV_hue

        public final int getHSV_hue()
        Returns the Hue of this color.
        Returns:
        what "color" this color is

      • getHSV_sat

        public final double getHSV_sat()
        Returns the vividness of this color. A lower saturation means the color is closer to white, a higher saturation means the color is more true to its hue.
        Returns:
        the HSV-version saturation

      • getHSV_val

        public final double getHSV_val()
        Returns the brightness of this color. A lower value means the color is closer to black, a higher value means the color is more true to its hue.
        Returns:
        the HSV-version brightness

      • getHSL_hue

        public final int getHSL_hue()
        Returns the Hue of this color. Same exact value as getHSV_hue().
        Returns:
        this.getHSV_hue();

      • getHSL_sat

        public final int getHSL_sat()
        Returns the amount of "color" in the color. A lower saturation means the color is more grayer, a higher saturation means the color is more colorful.
        Returns:
        the HSL-version saturation

      • getHSL_lum

        public final int getHSL_lum()
        Returns how "light" or "dark" the color is. A lower luminosity means the color is closer to black, a higher luminosity means the color is closer to white.
        Returns:
        the HSL-version luminosity

      • newColorHSV

        public static Color newColorHSV(int hue,
                double saturation,
                double value)
        Returns a new Color object, given hue, saturation, and value. The parameters correspond to HSV, *not* HSL. To create a new color with HSL, see the newColorHSL() method.
        Parameters:
        hue - the "color" of the color. Must be between 0 and 360.
        saturation - the vividness of the color. A lower saturation means the color is closer to white, a higher saturation means the color is more true to its hue. Must be a decimal between 0 and 1.
        value - the brightness of the color. A lower value means the color is closer to black, a higher value means the color is more true to its hue. Must be a decimal between 0 and 1.
        Returns:
        a new Color object with hsv(hue, sat, val)

      • newColorHSL

        public static Color newColorHSL(int hue,
                double saturation,
                double luminosity)
        Returns a new Color object, given hue, saturation, and luminosity.
        Parameters:
        hue - the "color" of the color. Same as the hue in HSV. Must be between 0 and 360.
        saturation - the amount of "color" in the color. A lower saturation means the color is more grayer, a higher saturation means the color is more colorful. Not the same as saturation in HSV. Must be a decimal between 0 and 1.
        luminosity - how "light" or "dark" the color is. A lower luminosity means the color is closer to black, a higher luminosity means the color is closer to white. Must be a decimal between 0 and 1.
        Returns:
        a new Color object with hsl(hue, sat, lum)
